Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Molecular Modules of Aggression; Maternal Behavior in the African Cichlid Astatotilapia Burtoni
Award.AbstractNarration: In all animals, aggression is a complex social behavior with multiple causes and manifestations. Growing evidence suggests that different mechanisms underlie different forms of aggression. This project examines different forms of aggression in the African cichlid fish Astatotilapia burtoni. Aggression in males of this species is associated with territoriality and is regulated by social factors and testosterone. Previous research has identified brain regions, physiological mechanisms and patterns of gene expression that underlie the variety of aggression levels in males. Laboratory stock females do not care for their young nor do they show stereotypical forms of aggression. However, aggression can be induced in the laboratory through manipulation of the social environment. This form of female aggression, as in males, is associated with elevated testosterone levels. Recent observations of a newly acquired wild stock reveal a "good mother" phenotype that includes defensive aggression to protect free-swimming fry. This new stock will allow a comparison of different hormone levels correlated with different levels of maternal aggression. Furthermore, the availability of genomic tools for this species (a cDNA microarray) will allow the identification of gene expression associated with maternal aggression. The pattern of gene expression can be then compared between natural maternal aggression, induced female aggression and territorial male aggression. This work will answer questions regarding the extent of overlap between the gene sets that regulate each of these forms of aggression and will identify specific subsets of the gene expression pattern that are uniquely associated with male, female, and/or maternal forms of aggression. Through collaboration between the Renn Lab in the biology department and the Jones team in the math department, undergraduates at Reed College will engage in cutting edge genomic research and rigorous statistical analysis of datasets incorporating measures of behavior, physiology and gene expression.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Results Summary

This project aimed to address the mechanistic basis of good maternal care in the mouth-brooding cichlid fish by investigating changes in hormone levels and brain gene expression that would be localized to identify specific brain regions involved.  These fish brood their young in their mouths for 2-3 weeks and then transition to a high maternal care phenotype that includes territory defense and continued care. Using gene expression microarray technology, we investigated the difference between females in a strain that shows high maternal care and another that shows low maternal care. We found a small number of genes that showed a dramatic change in expression level at the transition to the maternal state only in a fish strain that shows high maternal care. We also found differences in hormone levels that were predictive of good maternal care. These data were compared to previous work that had investigated brain gene expression in male fish that transition between territorial and non-territorial. That analysis suggested that some changes in gene expression are associated specifically with territoriality and aggression while others are associated with maternal care behaviors.

 

 

Publication and Dissemination

Research under this project has resulted in 3 publications with two more in preparation for publication this year. The results have also been presented by the PI and numerous students at several national and international meetings including invited workshops and topical symposia.

Faculty Development

Through this project, the Biology PI initiated collaborations with researchers at Oregon State University, North Carolina State University, and Louisiana State University. This later collaboration has formed the basis of a new NSF collaborative project that will further the research initiated under this award.

 

Personnel Development

Over the course of this project, one technician and one postdoctoral fellow were trained under and contributed to this work. The technician is now completing a PhD at another institution and the postdoctoral fellow is working on the continuation of this research project.

 

Student Development

Over the course of this project, 23 undergraduate thesis and summer students from Biology, Psychology and Mathematics have been trained on and contributed to this work. Nearly half of these students have gone on to graduate or medical school. The majority of them had the opportunity to present research findings at a national conference.

 

Pedegogy

The fish and techniques developed in this project have been adapted for use in the undergraduate Animal Behavior course at Reed College.
